overview: This subject introduces students to the basics of harmonic/melodic and rhythmic language for improvised music specifically and contemporary music generally, with a clear focus on consolidating, reconstructing and manipulating the fundamentals of music within the brain of the improvising musician.
Students attend Languages of Music (lecture/workshop) which is supported by practical small group tutorials for each of the three areas of: harmonic, rhythmic and practical devices.
The assessment combines written examination and practical application.
intended learning outcomes: apply an understanding of the fundamental elements of western tonal music and its structures;
develop knowledge of how these fundamental structures work together in jazz standards;
sing, perform and transcribe vocal/instrumental examples from the improvised music canon;
identify and perform selected patterns and polyrhythms;
sing and perform selected harmonic and melodic structures;
apply basic keyboard technique to composition and accompanying.

assessments.description: Languages of Music - four assessments of 5% each: 200-word essay, 2-minute presentation; workbook (5 hours of work required), 2-minute test. 20 hours (of work required)
Languages of Music written exam. 800 words (equivalent)
Three 4-minute short in-class tests: Harmonic Devices; Rhythmic Devices; Practical Devices. 30 hours (of work required)
Three 4-minute practical exams: Harmonic Devices; Rhythmic Devices; Practical Devices. 30 hours (of work required)
Hurdle requirement:. Students must attend a minimum of 75% of all scheduled classes.

Semester 1.Contact hours: 51 hours, comprising one 2‐hour Languages of Music lecture/workshop, and three 45‐minute online practical tutorials per week.

Prescribed texts: There are no specifically prescribed or recommended texts for this subject.
